displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now one question that patients always ask me is “Is it possible you know for the uh testosterone to make the cancer worse?” In other words, could it accelerate or stimulate or speed up the cancer? Patient: Uh huh. My thoughts also. Doctor: And you know that was one of the very first things we thought of when we were designing these trials for uh patients and the first trial of this approach started in around twenty thirteen. And so we’ve been doing this for three or four years now. And in our initial studies, fortunately we did not see any cases where prostate cancer appeared to accelerate. Patient: Oh okay. Doctor: So we basically saw one of three patterns. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the first is, which is the most promising, is that the cancer goes into remission. That’s about one-third of patients. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then in about one-third of patients, the cancer neither grows nor shrinks. So it basically stabilizes. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And that stabilization typically lasts anywhere from six to twelve months. So it’s not permanent. Patient: Uh huh.

Family Member: I brought juice. Doctor: Remember that? Doctor: I saw him last time. It was a whole lot of fun. A whole lot of fun. Doctor: How have the sugars been at home? Patient: They’ve been doing good. Doctor: Yeah? Good, good or mah good? Patient: Mah good. Doctor: Okay. Why is that? Because you’re (clears voice) Patient: Um, maybe a little of both. Doctor: Okay. Patient: But I, I, you know, I’m religious in checking my sugars. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright, and uh, I do need to feel your tummy. (Dr. examining patient) Patient: Mm hmm. Doctor: And urine, no problems? Patient: No problems. Doctor: Ok. So should we go back on the chemo? Patient: I think so. I think so, 'cause-- Doctor: Yeah, because the last time your PSA came down and, you know, I think this tearing, like I said, it could possibly be from the chemotherapy, so-- Patient: I mean, if I'm doin' good on it, Doctor: It’s very much Patient: -let's keep goin'. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s on the uh - it’s called the left iliac lymph node. So the left iliac lymph node is basically um where the blood vessel called the aorta splits up into the two iliac arteries. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then there are lymph nodes on each side. So I would say if I, if I could go through your abdomen like three inches, I’d hit it; it’s on the left side. Patient: Now I did have uh a gist and I had that surgery July the thirteenth. I remember that was in the stomach. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? Well I guess they’re two independent things then. Doctor: It’s two, it’s two independent things. You are a extremely low risk gist tumor. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And and the risk is not determined by the size. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s determined by um how rapidly the cells are dividing, so there’s something that’s called a mitosis. Patient: Uh hum.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed
Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: I could eat nothing for about, about at least about two days. Doctor: Okay so let me send me over to chemo. Okay? We’ll do the chemo today, but meanwhile I’m going to call our radiologist and see if they can tell me something about the CAT scan. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? Then I’ll come over there and talk to you about it. Patient: Let me ask you something, let me ask you something Dr. B____. What is what is better, CAT scan or ah MRI? Doctor: It depends on what part of the body we’re looking at. But a CAT scan is pretty good, it’s a pretty good test. If we don’t find something or need to look at it more. Patient: You said it’s not showing on the… Doctor: Well not when we looked quickly, but uh you know we need a radiologists when – that’s why we have that specialty who reads CAT scans. Okay and I’m not one. (laughs) Patient: Yeah, I get it. Doctor: Okay, So as I get things… Patient: I’m gonna wait here until you get back. Cause, definitely how I’m tired and I’m gonna lay down man. Doctor: Yeah, okay. So as we get things sorted out I will come over and talk to you. Patient: Do I have to get any more shots today?

Family Member: Well what is the something? Doctor: Something is an oral medication. It’s a new oral hormonal therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s a second hormone therapy that given in connection with the injection of hormone therapy we believe may produce better outcomes than just injecting the hormone by itself. Patient: But even with that, that’s still just to slow it down; it’s not to cure anything. It’s kind of take it to add a little bit more Doctor: That’s correct. Everything that we have discussed today frankly is not really curative in terms of its potential. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Because there isn’t any. Doctor: Right. Patient: Okay, And um, now with that, and I guess we can talk about it when we decide what we’re going to do. Does that involve a placebo? Doctor: Uhm. Patient: If that involves a placebo – Doctor: One of the two trials. The hormone therapy trial does involve a placebo. The other one does not. The radiotherapy trial does not.

Family Member: Hm Hmm. Doctor: you can sorta plan it out. So, the week that’s the scariest is if you get your chemo and Christmas and all those people are there seven to ten days after, that’s dangerous. Healthcare Professional: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Okay, but, if it’s the twenty, you know the eighteenth day of the cycle… Patient: So, apply the no-fly rule. Doctor: ‘Cuz again if Healthcare Professional: Yes. Doctor: his counts are already up and ready for the next cycle, that’s the safest. Family Member: Oh, got it. Got it. Yep, I see that. I see that. Math makes sense. Yep. Family Member: Now, I just have to remember it. (pause) Patient: We’ll see, we’ll just try to make it happen. We’ll just schedule it out. Family Member: Mmm. I think we might go with the artificial, artificial tree. Aren’t we glad we

Family Member: Uh, huh. Doctor: are possible side effects of these medications. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: But those are things that you cannot just sit at home and wait until your next appointment and you elicit- Family Member: I don’t know who to call. I’m a registered nurse. Doctor: I know. Family Member: I’m going to keep my eye on- Family Member: Yes. Yes. Doctor: Because you have the training already. Family Member: You’re going to have to listen to me, J___, okay? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: But she said is so vitally important -

Patient: I haven’t talked to him. Doctor: No but when they did the testing? Patient: Oh he said it’s worse. Doctor: It’s worse? Patient: A little worse, yeah. Doctor: Really? Patient: Yeah. The um… Doctor: So the strength was worse? Patient: Right. Doctor: That was worse. That would be the reason then to do… Patient: Right, right. Doctor: …you know to lean towards surgery. Because if it’s going to take the pressure off the nerve…

Patient: I’ll just have one of those for some for some nourishment, water and uh you know I’m, I’m more a fizzy water guy. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: So, for, you know, there’s a thing called Ice that’s like. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: Like a lot of juice in it. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: And there’s something else that my mom gave me, it’s just like a flavoring of a, you know? Doctor: Okay. So you’re, you’re doing what you can. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Let’s get M___. Okay. Yeah. (Door opening) Patient: I’ve been taking my uh you know the Calcitrate. That doesn’t sit well with me. Doctor: Yeah. Why don’t you give it a break? I mean you’ve been on it a while. Let’s give it a break. Patient: Because I, I know what to use it. The one I’ve got is four pills two times twice a day. And when I take the ones at night, man they just.

Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But typically we want to have two options. Number one would be switching from that pill to a different pill. And the second pill is called Xtandi. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That is also known as Enzalutamide. Got a long name. The short name is Xtandi, the long name is Enzalutamide. And this is a pill you take it every day and it’s also four pills at a time. Four pills all at once. The dose is one hundred sixty milligrams. So it’s a little bit different from the Abiraterone. And this one does not require Prednisone, no Prednisone for this one. So it’s one less thing to take. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: The second option for some patients, whose cancer is progressing more rapidly, especially in those that its causing symptoms, like bone pain for example. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Be to go to a intravenous chemotherapy. Okay. I don’t think I’m going to recommend that for you right now because your symptoms seem to be relatively mild. I’m not fully convinced to whether the pain that you had yesterday was attracted to cancer or could’ve been through something . I’ll try this route Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The chemotherapy has a name. It’s called Docetaxel and it has a second name and that is Taxotere. And this is given through the vein, intravenous, also called I.V. Intravenous I.V. It’s given once every few weeks. And I’m writing this down as an option just so you know what we talked about. But at this point in time, um I think that your cancer is progressing relatively slowly, if at all. Probably at slowly. And I don’t see any immediate need right now to recommend the chemotherapy. But it is an option, we’ll save that for later. I wanna focus our conversation now on the fresh option, which is the Xtandi. So in general in patients who have previously received Abiraterone, that could’ve been you, you would’ve been taking it but you were unable to get access to it for the last two months. Patient: Right. Doctor: If if that is no longer affected then the second drug, Xtandi, uh typically works for about six, sometimes nine months. So it, it doesn’t work for years and years but it does give us a little bit more time before we have to recommend the chemotherapy.

Patient: I ain’t seen it in my lymph nodes. I check my lymph nodes. I ain’t seen none in my lymph nodes. Doctor: Well, you can’t see it. It’s inside when I do scans. So the good part is you don’t hurt or feel bad. Thank goodness. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that’s great. But it doesn’t mean that we don’t do stuff because that’s why I check scans because it’s inside. So that’s, that’s why. Family Member: Um. Okay. Doctor: So that’s where we’re at. Family Member: That’s the proper response. Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: And, uh, I’m still ready to ask. Doctor: Yep? Family Member: Oh. I ran into a lady.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah and so we’ll be looking to do that anyway. But I agree with you. We should make that decision you know before then. Patient: We will. I will talk to my wife. As a matter of fact when we leave here I’m going to head to the rehab. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And the four of us can kind of you know talk. But I think that’s the direction that we’ll probably go- Doctor: Once you have a clearer picture of you know which way you want to go, whether it’s radiotherapy with hormones for now or hormones plus or minus some secondary therapy which may work better, then I would also like to talk to you about some of the clinical trials in each of those categories. Since they are mutually exclusive right now. It’s kind of either like a radiotherapy based trial or hormone therapy plus something new. So once - Family Member: I’m sorry; say that one more time. You say it’s two? What are the two again? Doctor: The -the two general like avenues that we could go; one is radiotherapy to target that lymph node. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And we have a trial to do that through H__. And the other one is to skip the radiotherapy and go directly to hormone therapy. And then we have a trial looking to see whether combining something with hormone therapy is better than hormone therapy alone. Patient: Uh hum. Family Member: Well what is the something?

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Your blood pressure and stuff, we’ll send those in. Patient: Okay. Because I said my vitamins, that’s what, that boosts me up. Because like when I’m fatigued I can’t get up, I take one of those vitamins. Doctor: That helps. Patient: And I’m off and running. Yes sir. I’m off running man. Doctor: Now are you still taking prednisone? Patient: That’s what I’m like, that’s what I was trying to tell you. That’s the way he didn’t know what I take. He said you still taking the prednisone Doctor: So you need a new script? Patient: Yeah I need a new script, all of that. Doctor: Because even with this new chemo I need to continue the prednisone. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s why I’m telling you.

Patient: This would be two. Doctor: Yeah. We’ll do three more of this um because again there’s a little interruption, there’s radiation, you know so we’ll just do four total Patient: Yeah okay. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Did you make a comment once that um that chemo doesn’t go up the skull or up to the brain or something like that? Doctor: It doesn’t typically penetrate to go to brain tissue, but it will penetrate to skull because that’s part of the bone. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’ll target the area even though you had it radiated. It still would be going around Patient: Okay. Doctor: the neck. It just doesn’t go into the brain. Patient: I don’t want that to come back. Doctor: Yes, we don’t want it to come back either.
